photo.description: The Leshan Giant Buddha (Simplified Chinese: 乐山大佛; Traditional Chinese: 樂山大佛; Pinyin: Lèshān Dàfó) is the tallest stone Buddha statue in the world, built during the Tang Dynasty (618-907). It is carved out of a cliff face that lies at the confluence of the Minjiang, Dadu and Qingyi rivers in the southern part of Sichuan province in China, near the city of Leshan. The stone sculpture faces Mount Emei, with the rivers flowing below his feet. The Mount Emei Scenic Area, including Leshan Giant Buddha Scenic Area has been listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1996. History Construction was started in 713 AD, led by a Chinese monk named Haitong. He hoped that the Buddha would calm the turbulent waters that plagued the shipping vessels travelling down the river. When funding for the project was threatened, he is said to have gouged out his own eyes to show his piety and sincerity. Construction was completed by his disciples ninety years later. Apparently the massive construction resulted in so much stone being removed from the cliff face and deposited into the river below that the currents were indeed altered by the statue, making the waters safe for passing ships. Dimensions Standing 71 metres tall, the statue depicts a seated Maitreya Buddha with his hands resting on his knees. His shoulders are twenty-eight metres wide and his smallest toenail is large enough to easily accommodate a seated person. There is a local saying: "The mountain is a Buddha and the Buddha is a mountain". This is partially because the mountain range in which the Leshan Giant Buddha is located is thought to be shaped like a slumbering Buddha when seen from the river, with the Leshan Giant Buddha as its heart. info from wikipedia

photo.title: 乐山大佛 Leshan Giant Buddha

photo.title: Giant Buddha

photo.description: The Leshan Giant Buddha was built during the Tang Dynasty (618–907AD). It is carved out of a cliff face that lies at the confluence of the Minjiang, Dadu and Qingyi rivers in the southern part of Sichuan province in China, near the city of Leshan. The stone sculpture faces Mount Emei, with the rivers flowing below his feet. It is the largest carved stone Buddha in the world and it is by far the tallest pre-modern statue in the world. At 71 metres tall, the statue depicts a seated Maitreya Buddha with his hands resting on his knees. His shoulders are 28 metres wide and his smallest toenail is large enough to easily accommodate a seated person. (From Wikipedia, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leshan_Giant_Buddha)
photo.title: Leshan, Big Buddha

photo.description: The Leshan Giant Buddha is a statue of Maitreya (a Bodhisattva usually represented as a very stout monk with a broad smile on his face and with his naked breast and paunch exposed to view) in sitting posture. The Buddha is located to the east of Leshan City, Sichuan Province, at the confluence of three rivers, namely, Min River, Qingyi River, and Dadu River. Begun in the year 713 in the Tang Dynasty, and finished in the year 803, the statue took people more than 90 years to carve. During these years, thousands of workers had expended their efforts and wisdom on the project. As the biggest carved stone Buddha in the world, Leshan Giant Buddha is featured in poetry, song and story. It is 71 meters (about 233 feet) high, and has three-meter-long (about 11 feet) fingers. The eight-meter-long (about 27 feet) instep is big enough for one hundred people to sit on and the 28-meter-wide (about 92 feet) shoulder is large enough to be a basketball playground.
photo.title: Leshan Giant Buddha

photo.description: Me vs the Buddha. OK, he's like waaay bigger and cooler. At 71m high, the Giant Buddha is the largest seated Buddha in the world, carved out of the solid cliff. I am however less 1.75m high. I couldn't even reach the top of his sandle. Kinda felt like Jack and the Beanstock.

photo.description: The Leshan Giant Buddha has survived 1200 years of rainfall and earthquakes, including the 2008 Sichuan earthquake, but now air pollution is taking its toll - the Buddha is suffering a blackened nose and smears of dirt across the face. Since 1996, the Leshan Giant Buddha Scenic Area has been listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

photo.description: Built near the confluence of the Minjiang, Dadu and Qingyi rivers, near the city of Leshan in Sichuan, this stone sculpture is the largest carved stone Buddha in the world. Today, this Leshan Giant Buddha is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Sichuan.

photo.title: Arch On Trail To Giant Buddha

photo.description: In ancient times Leshan was known as Jiazhou and was reputed as the place 'Where there is the most beautiful landscape in all Sichuan, there is Jiazhou'. It was famous for its abundance of the Chinese flowering crab-apple and long ago was given the title of 'Haitang (crab-apple) Xiangguo (fragrant city)'. Nowadays Leshan is particularly well known as a city of National Key Tourist Attractions due to its natural landscape and wealth of cultural relics.
photo.title: Leshan Giant Buddha

photo.description: The Buddha's right hand is visible in the bottom right of the pic. We didn't have time to go down those steps.
photo.title: Giant Buddha park in Leshan

photo.description: Giant Buddha in Leshan, Sichuan, China
photo.title: Giant Buddha in Leshan, Sichuan, China

photo.description: And here he is, the big man. The largest seated Buddha in the world. He was carved out of the rock to protect fishermen from the currents in the river at his feet. In a delicious twist, the rock excavated to reveal the Buddha (who had been sat there all along!), levelled off the riverbed and calmed the currents.
photo.title: Giant Buddha park in Leshan

photo.description: As a day trip from Chengdu, Lisa and I went to see a Buddha who is apparently quite big; giant, some say. It was a really misty, atmospheric day which made the trees and pagodas look amazing.
photo.title: Giant Buddha park in Leshan

photo.description: Note careful placement of life-size figurines to show the size of the Buddha's head.
photo.title: Giant Buddha park in Leshan

photo.description: The Buddha is holding out pretty well.

photo.description: One of the many Buddhas on the way to the giant Buddha. I am told it is good luck to touch his belly button. It must have worked :)
